subject: RE: [junit] checking for test coverage
msgSnippet: There is a pre-built ANT optional task that hooks into JProbe s coverage tool (JPCoverage) but alas you have to purchase the software and it s not really JUnit
messageBody:
There is a pre-built ANT optional task that hooks into JProbe's coverage
tool (JPCoverage) but alas you have to purchase the software and it's not
really JUnit specific (good or bad). An example report using this task can
be found at:

http://icarus.apache.org/~sbailliez/jakarta-ant/coverage/

Chuck

-----Original Message-----
From: Chris Eppstein [mailto:ceppstein@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2002 2:03 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] checking for test coverage


Thanks to all for your replies. To recap:

The filename matching system that David proposed was my first thought as
well and it could be implemented as an Ant task easily enough so that can be
used to fail a build if a test case is missing, etc... I had started to
write this utility when I decided to email the list and make sure I wasn't
re-inventing the wheel. I think that this approach is a good first step but
it doesn't give us a look into the code and it would be difficult to handle
interfaces (for which I rarely write a unit test).

I looked at NoUnit but I cannot get it to run with Java 1.4 -- it looks
promising though. Quilt is the most ambitious of the open source projects
and it also looks to be very promising -- but is still pre-alpha and
probably not ready for use in a corporate setting.

Integration with Ant is, of-course, a big plus for any utility that can be
used for this task. Looks like there's some definate room for improvement in
this area. Does anyone else have some suggestions?

Chris

-----Original Message-----
From: Vladimir Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2002 9:33 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] checking for test coverage


> Does anyone know of any utilities that can check for test coverage.


You can have a look at Quilt: http://quilt.sourceforge.net

Off the record: it would be interesting to know what is the average
coverage of the Test First Design method: 80%, 90%, 95%, 100%?

-Vladimir

Vladimir Bossicard
